questions.text: The structures marked as “A” and “B” in the image below are developmentally derived from
questions.solution:
• The structures marked as “A” and “B” in the above image are outer Annulus fibrosus and inner Nucleus Pulposus of Intervertebral disc.
  • Nucleus pulposus is entirely derived from the notochord, whereas the annulus fibrosus is sclerotome-derived structure.

Development:

  1. During the fourth week, sclerotome cells migrate around the spinal cord and notochord to merge with cells from the opposing somite on the other side of the neural tube. As development continues, the sclerotome portion of each somite also undergoes a process called resegmentation.
  2. Resegmentation occurs when the caudal half of each sclerotome grows into and fuses with the cephalic half of each subjacent sclerotome.
  3. Thus, each vertebra is formed from the combination of the caudal half of one somite and the cranial half of its neighbor.
  4. Mesenchymal cells between cephalic and caudal parts of the original sclerotome segment do not proliferate but fill the space between two pre cartilaginous vertebral bodies. In this way, they contribute to formation of the intervertebral disc.
  5. Although the notochord regresses entirely in the region of vertebral bodies, it persists and enlarges in the region of intervertebral disks, leading to the formation of nucleus pulposus.

questions.text: The Phase 2, in the ventricular myocyte action potential, shown in the image below, is due to:

choices.text: Calcium channels remaining open longer than sodium channels
Increased membrane permeability to potassium ions
Rapid inactivation of the Na+ channels

questions.solution:
Action potential: electrical stimulation created by a sequence of ion fluxes through specialized channels in the membrane (sarcolemma) of cardiomyocytes that leads to cardiac contraction.

Action potential in cardiomyocytes:

The action potential in typical cardiomyocytes is composed of 5 phases (0-4), beginning and ending with phase 4.

Phase 4: The resting phase

  1. The resting potential in a cardiomyocytes is −90 mV due to a constant outward leak of K+ through inward rectifier channels.
  2. Na+ and Ca2+ channels are closed at resting TMP.

Phase 0: Depolarization

  1. An action potential triggered in a neighbouring cardiomyocytes or pacemaker cell causes the TMP to rise above −90 mV.
  2. Fast Na+ channels start to open one by one and Na+ leaks into the cell, causing further raise in TMP.
  3. TMP approaches −70mV, the threshold potential in cardiomyocytes, i.e. the point at which enough fast Na+ channels have opened to generate a self-sustaining inward Na+ current.
  4. The large Na+ current rapidly depolarizes the TMP to 0 mV and slightly above 0 mV for a transient period of time called the overshoot;
  5. Fast Na+ channels close (recall that fast Na+ channels are time-dependent).
  6. L-type (“long-opening”) Ca2+ channels open when the TMP is greater than −40 mV and cause a small but steady influx of Ca2+ down its concentration gradient.

Phase 1: Early repolarization

  1. TMP is now slightly positive.
  2. Some K+ channels open briefly and an outward flow of K+ returns the TMP to approximately 0 mV.

Phase 2: The plateau phase

  1. L-type Ca2+ channels are still open and there is a small, constant inward current of Ca2+. This becomes significant in the excitation-contraction coupling process described below.
  2. K+ leaks out down its concentration gradient through delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  3. These two countercurrent are electrically balanced, and the TMP is maintained at a plateau just below 0 mV throughout phase 2.

Phase 3: Repolarization

  1. Ca2+ channels are gradually inactivated.
  2. Persistent outflow of K+, now exceeding Ca2+ inflow, brings TMP back towards resting potential of −90 mV to prepare the cell for a new cycle of depolarization.
  3. Normal transmembrane ionic concentration gradients are restored by returning Na+ and Ca2+ ions to the extracellular environment, and K+ ions to the cell interior.
  4. The pumps involved include the sarcolemmal Na+-Ca2+ exchanger, Ca2+-ATPase and Na+-K+-ATPase.

questions.text: The biochemical pathway shown in the image below is ___.
questions.solution:
• The Cori cycle (also known as the Lactic acid cycle), named after its discoverers, Carl Ferdinand Cori and Gerty Cori.
  • It refers to the metabolic pathway in which lactate produced by anaerobic glycolysis in the muscles moves to the liver and is converted to glucose, which then returns to the muscles and is metabolized back to lactate.

This cycle can be summarized as follows:

  1. The conversion of glucose to lactic acid, or lactate, by anaerobic glycolysis in skeletal muscle cells.
  2. Diffusion of lactate from muscle cells into the bloodstream, by which it is transported to the liver
  3. The conversion of lactate to glucose by hepatic gluconeogenesis
  4. Diffusion of glucose from the hepatocytes into the bloodstream, by which it is transported back to the skeletal muscle cells, thereby closing the cycle.

Significance:

  • The cycle's importance is based on the prevention of lactic acidosis in the muscle under anaerobic conditions. However, normally before this happens the lactic acid is moved out of the muscles and into the liver.
  • The cycle is also important in producing ATP, an energy source, during muscle activity.
  • The contribution of Cori cycle lactate to overall glucose production increases with fasting duration.
  • The drug metformin can cause lactic acidosis in patients with renal failure because metformin inhibits the hepatic gluconeogenesis of the Cori cycle, particularly the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?

choices.text: C is more potent than A
B is more potent than A

questions.solution:
In the above image, drug B is a competitive antagonist.

In competitive antagonism, the DRC is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is drug A > drug C > drug B.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is drug A = drug B > drug C.

questions.text: The type of antibody demonstrated here is
questions.solution:
IgA occurs in two forms – Serum IgA and Secretory IgA

Serum IgA is a monomer

Secretory IgA is a dimer, formed by two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide known as J-chain.

Secretory Ig A is synthesised by plasma cells situated near the mucosal or glandular epithelium. The J chain is also produced by plasma cells.

IgM is a polymer, consisting of 5 subunits, which are joined by J-chain.

IgG, IgD and IgE are monomers

questions.text: Identify the bodies shown in the Histological image below. Patient was diagnosed with meningioma.
questions.solution:
• The above histological image shows psammoma bodies.
  • Psammoma bodies (PBs) are concentric lamellated calcified structures, observed most commonly in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC), meningioma, and papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of ovary but have rarely been reported in other neoplasms and nonneoplastic lesions.
  • PBs are said to represent a process of dystrophic calcification.
  • Ultrastructural study of PTC has shown that thickening of the base lamina in vascular stalk of neoplastic papillae followed by thrombosis, calcification, and tumor cell necrosis leads to formation of PBs.
  • Studies on serous cystadenocarcinoma of ovary and meningioma, however, revealed that collagen production by neoplastic cells and subsequent calcification was responsible for the formation of PBs.
  • The existence of some precursor forms of PBs was reported in meningiomas and more recently in PTC, which were mostly in the form of extracellular hyaline globules surrounded by well-preserved neoplastic cells or in a smaller number of cases intracytoplasmic bodies liberated from intact tumor cells.

questions.text: The method of identification used in forensic lab as shown in the image below is based on
questions.solution:
• Poroscopy is a method of personal identification through the comparison of the impressions of sweat pores (present on friction ridges of palmar and plantar surfaces).
  • The method was discovered and developed by Edmond Locard in 1912.
  • It includes the study of the configuration, size, and relative position of the pores in human skin.

questions.text: Which of the following sampling technique is depicted in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the technique of stratified random sampling. A stratified random sample is obtained by:

  1. Separating the population into non-overlapping groups called strata
  2. Then obtaining a proportional simple random sample from each group
  3. The individuals within each group should be similar in some way

This method of sampling avoids bias for being discriminatory for a particular group.

Option A) Simple random sampling: Sample drawn in such a way that every element in the population has an equal probability of being included.

Option C) Snowball sampling: This method is used when the population cannot be located in a specific place, and therefore, it is difficult to access this population.

Option D) Cluster sampling: This method is used when creating a sampling frame is nearly impossible due to the large size of the population. In this approach, the population is divided into clusters based on geographic location. A list of all clusters is created, and investigators randomly select a number of clusters to be included. Next, they list all individuals within these selected clusters and conduct another round of random selection to obtain a final random sample, similar to simple random sampling. This method is called multistage sampling because the selection process occurs in two stages: first, the selection of eligible clusters, and second, the selection of individuals from within those clusters.

questions.text: The ECG wave as shown in the image below is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
The above ECG wave characteristically depicts Digoxin effect.

Digoxin effect refers to the presence on the ECG of:

  • Downsloping ST depression with a characteristic “Salvador Dali sagging” or “Hockey Stick” appearance.
  • Flattened, inverted, or biphasic T waves.
  • Shortened QT interval.

Additional ECG Features:

  • Mild PR interval prolongation of up to 240ms (due to increased vagal tone).
  • Prominent U waves.
  • Peaking of the terminal portion of the T waves.
  • J point depression (usually in leads with tall R waves).

QRS complex / ST segment changes:

  • The morphology of the QRS complex / ST segment is variously described as either “slurred”, “sagging” or “scooped” and resembling either a “reverse tick”, “hockey stick” or “Salvador Dali’s moustache”.

questions.text: Exclamation mark hair as shown in the image below is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
• The exclamation mark hair is the characteristic feature seen in Alopecia areata.
  • Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease which causes non scarring patches of hair loss.
  • It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease which occurs in genetically predisposed patients.
  • The most characteristic lesion initially is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia which has short extractable broken hairs called as exclamation mark hair.

questions.text: A 30 years old male presents with continuous discomfort in the right hypochondrium and on examination shows presence of enlarged liver 8cm below the costal margins. The image below shows CT radiograph. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The above image shows CT scan of the liver with hydatid cyst seen as a hypodense lesion with internal septation.

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus, and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

Causative agent:

There are two main strains which include:

  1. Echinococcus granulosus: commoner
    • pastoral: dog is a main host; most common form
    • sylvatic: wolf is a main host
  2. Echinococcus alveolaris/multilocularis: less common but more invasive; fox is a main host

Investigation:

  • CT examination reveals fluid density cyst, with frequent peripheral focal areas of calcification, usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • Septation and daughter cysts may be visualised. The water-lily sign indicates a cyst with floating, undulating membrane, caused by a detached endocyst.
  • May also show hyperdense internal septa representing a spoke wheel pattern within a cyst.

questions.text: Identify the X-ray radiographic view of skull as shown in the image below
questions.solution:
• Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.
  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses (oblique view)
  • Ethmoidal cells
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Odontoid process (if it is just below the mentum, it confirms adequate extension of the head

 

Other views:

 

  • Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of skull principally used for viewing mastoid cells.
  • The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head and is at angle of 25° caudal to radiographic plate.
  • This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones.
  • Caldwell's view (or Occipitofrontal view) is a radiographic view of skull, where X-ray plate is angled at 20° to orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to radiographic plate.
  • It is commonly used to get better view of frontal sinuses.

Towne view:

  • It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck.
  • The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hair-line.
  • The result is clear image of the posterior portion of the skull including the foramen magnum.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: Identify the fracture as shown in the X-ray radiograph below
questions.solution:
The above image shows fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, commonly known as Bennet’s fracture.

  • Bennet’s fracture is defined as an intra-articular two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which may occur due to forced abduction of the first metacarpal.
  • When an intra-articular fracture of the 1st metacarpal is comminuted, producing at least three parts, it is referred to as a Rolando fracture which has a worse prognosis.
  • The fracture requires open reduction and fixation if there is significant displacement (>3 mm).
  • If malunion or non-union occurs, a pseudoarthrosis may result.

questions.text: Identify the Mapleson’s circuit type, shown in the above image
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mapleson’s Type B breathing circuit.

Mapleson’s breathing systems are used for delivering oxygen and anesthetic agents and to eliminate carbon dioxide during anesthesia. They consist of different components: Fresh gas flow, reservoir bag, breathing tubes, expiratory valve, and patient connection. There are six types of Mapleson’s circuits denoted by A – F.

  • Mapleson’s A (Magill circuit):
    • In Mapleson A system, fresh gas flow (FGF) enters the circuit near the reservoir bag away from the patient end.
    • A corrugated tubing connects the reservoir bag near the machine end, to the adjustable pressure limiting valve (APL) at the patient end of the system.
    • Reservoir bag is used for monitoring respiration as well as ventilating the patient. It also acts as a reservoir of gas and protects the patient from excessive pressure within the breathing system.

Advantages:

  1. Best circuit for spontaneous respiration as no rebreathing occurs with adequate flows.
  2. Less fresh gas flow is required during spontaneous respiration.

Disadvantages:

  1. Wastage of gases.
  2. Theatre pollution by Magill circuit.
  3. Mechanical ventilator should not be used with this circuit because the entire system becomes dead space.

 

  • MAPLESON B AND C:
    • They are similar in construction, with the fresh gas flow entry and the expiratory valves located at the patient end of the circuit and reservoir bag is at the machine end of the circuit, except that corrugated tubing is absent in Mapleson C.
    • They are not commonly used in anesthetic practice because the High flow of gases is needed to prevent rebreathing of CO2 and theatre pollution is maximum.
    • Also, fresh gas flow required is equal to peak inspiratory flow rate (20-25 lit/min) to prevent rebreathing.
    • Hence there is a lot of wastage of fresh gases.
  • Mapleson’s D:
    • The classic form of Mapleson D has a 6 mm tube that supplies the fresh gas from the machine. It connects to the T piece at the patient end and another limb of the T is attached to a wide bore corrugated tube to which the reservoir bag is attached and the expiratory valve is positioned near the bag.
    • This is the most commonly used circuit and is also the preferred circuit for controlled ventilation.
  • Mapleson’s E:
    • Mapleson E system is derived from Ayre's T piece configuration by adding tubing to the expiratory part of the circuit.
    • It acts as a fresh gas reservoir during inspiration. Its capacity should be more than the expected tidal volume.
    • It is mainly used in neonates, infants and pediatric patients who are less than 20 kg in weight or less than 5 years of age.
  • Mapleson’s F system:
    • It is a modification of Mapleson E by Jackson Rees and is known as Jackson Rees modification.
    • It has a 500 ml bag attached to the expiratory limb. This bag helps in respiratory monitoring or assisting the respiration.
    • It is most commonly used circuit in pediatric patients.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, the characteristic appearance marked by arrows, is seen as shown in the MRI image below
questions.solution:
The above image shows ovoid lesions with their long axis perpendicular to the ventricular surface called Dawson fingers (white arrows) which are characteristically seen in multiple sclerosis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is considered to be autoimmune in origin and is the most common demyelinating disease.

MRI is the study of choice in imaging multiple sclerosis because of its greater sensitivity than computed tomography in demonstrating plaques, both in the brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following maneuver is shown in the image below
questions.solution:
• The above image shows Pinard’s Maneuver which is used in the management of frank breech.
  • The Pinard maneuver may be needed with a frank breech to facilitate delivery of the legs, only after the fetal umbilicus has been reached. Pressure is exerted against the inner aspect of the knee. Flexion of the knee follows, and the lower leg is swept medially and out of the vagina.

Pinard’s maneuver:

  • Patient should be under general anaesthesia.
  • The palmer surface of obstetrician is to be introduce facing the ventral surface of foetus.
  • Breech is pushed up at least to the level of symphysis pubis.
  • Middle and index fingers should apply pressure in popliteal fossa and abduction of the fossa done, which causes partial flexion of leg.
  • Head is flexed by other hand abdominally i.e. externally.
  • The foot is brought down by grasping at the ankle by internal fingers.
  • Other leg is brought down in the same manner.

questions.text: “NESTROFT” screening method as shown in the image below is performed for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• “NESTROFT” (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a useful screening tool in the diagnosis of beta thalassemia trait.
  • The principle of NESTROFT is based on the limit of hypotonicity which the red cell can withstand. 
  • In this procedure 2 ml of 0.36% buffered saline is taken in a test tube, 20ml of whole blood is added to it, and is allowed to stand at room temperature.
  • After 20 minutes reading is taken on a NESTROFT stand on which a thin black line is marked.
  • If the line is visible through the solution, the test is considered as negative and if line is not visible it is considered as positive.
  • Positive test is due to the reduced osmotic fragility of red cells.

questions.text: The corneal ulcer seen after fluorescein staining as shown in the image below is caused by
questions.solution:
• The above image shows dendritic corneal ulcer which is characteristically seen in herpetic simplex keratitis.
  • Herpetic simplex keratitis, also known as herpetic keratoconjunctivitis and herpesviral keratitis, is a form of keratitis caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea

Signs & Symptoms:

  • Classic herpetic lesion consists of a linear branching corneal ulcer (dendritic ulcer).
  • Patients with epithelial keratitis complain of foreign-body sensation, light sensitivity, redness and blurred vision associated with Focal or diffuse reduction in corneal sensation.
  • In immune deficient patients or with the use of corticosteroids the ulcer may become large and in these cases it is called geographic ulcer.
  • Stromal keratitis manifests as a disc-shaped area of corneal edema.

Treatment:

  • Trifluridine 1% drops four times a day, or acyclovir 3% ointment five times a day, or 3% vidarabine ointment five times a day for 2 weeks.
  • Topical antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: The suprahyoid muscles marked as A, B, C and D in the image below are respectively
questions.solution:
The suprahyoid muscles marked as A, B, C and D in the image below are Geniohyoid, Digastric, Mylohyoid, and Stylohyoid respectively.

  • The suprahyoid muscles are four muscles located above the hyoid bone in the neck.
  • They are all pharyngeal muscles, with the exception of the geniohyoid muscle.
  • These four muscles have different actions, but in general assist in elevating the hyoid bone and widening the esophagus during swallowing.

Digastric muscle:

  • The digastric muscle has two bellies, anterior and posterior.
  • The posterior belly rises from the mastoid process of the cranium and slopes downward and forward.
  • The anterior belly arises from the mastoid notch on the inner surface of the mandibular body, which slopes downward and backward.
  • The two bellies connect at the intermediate tendon.
  • The intermediate tendon passes through a connective tissue loop attached to the hyoid bone.
  • Action: When the two bellies of the digastric contract, they pull upward on the hyoid bone; but if the hyoid is fixed from below, the digastric assists in opening of mouth as in yawning.

Mylohyoid Muscle:

  • The mylohyoid muscles are thin, flat muscles that form a sling inferior to the tongue supporting the floor of the mouth.
  • Action: The mylohyoid elevates the hyoid bone, tenses the floor of the mouth.

Geniohyoid Muscle:

  • The geniohyoid are short, narrow muscles that come into contact each other in the midline.
  • Action: The Geniohyoid pulls the hyoid bone antero superiorly, shortening the floor of the mouth and widening the pharynx during swallowing.

Stylohyoid Muscle:

  • The stylohyoid are long, thin muscles that are nearly parallel with the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Action: The Stylohyoid elevates and retracts the hyoid bone, elongating the floor of the mouth during swallowing.

questions.text: Which of the following points, denotes popliteal vein as marked in the image below of the popliteal fossa?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as A, B, C and D in the above image are Tibial nerve, Popliteal Vein, Popliteal artery and Common perineal nerve respectively.

The popliteal fossa is a diamond-shaped area found on the posterior side of the knee.

Its contents are (medial to lateral):

  • Popliteal artery
  • Popliteal vein
  • Tibial nerve
  • Common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve)

The tibial and common fibular nerves are the most superficial of the contents of the popliteal fossa. They are both branches of the sciatic nerve. The common fibular nerve follows the biceps femoris tendon, running along the lateral margin of the popliteal fossa.

The small saphenous vein pierces the popliteal fascia of the popliteal fossa to enter the diamond, and empty into the popliteal vein.

In the popliteal fossa, the deepest structure is the popliteal artery. It is a continuation of the femoral artery, and travels into the leg to supply it with blood.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts on the following stage of malarial parasite?
questions.solution:
The above image shows banana shaped gametocyte stage of P. Falciparum.

The antimalarial drugs which have gametocidal properties, include Chloroquine and Primaquine.

Primaquine, is primarily used as a tissue schizonticide for the purpose of reducing the likelihood of relapse due to hypnozoites of P. vivax and P. ovale. It is also a potent gametocidal drug.

Chloroquine acts primarily against erythrocytic asexual stages, although it has gametocidal properties.

questions.text: Stormy fermentation of lactose is caused by
questions.solution:
• In litmus milk, fermentation of lactose leads to formation of acid.
  • This acid coagulates the casein and the clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production.
  • The paraffin plug is pushed up and shreds of clot are seen sticking to the sides of the tube.
  • This is known as “Stormy fermentation” which is shown by clostridium perfringens.

questions.text: A patient died due to a stroke. Family members decide to donate the cadaver to the anatomy department of the medical college. During dissection of the cadaver, a resected specimen of the kidney appears as shown in the image below. What would be the likely disease that the patient has suffered from?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the gross specimen of a kidney showing small petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface that gives a flea-bitten appearance to the kidneys, which is characteristically seen in malignant hypertension.

Pathophysiology of malignant hypertension 

  • Vascular damage (due to chronic hypertension, arthritis, and coagulopathy) increases the permeability of small vessels to fibrinogen and other plasma proteins.
  • This causes endothelial injury and platelet deposition, which causes fibrinoid necrosis.
  • Kidneys become ischemic, which stimulates the renin-angiotensin system to produce angiotensin II; angiotensin II, in turn, causes renal vasoconstriction as well as increased aldosterone secretion and salt retention, which elevate the blood pressure even further.
  • This may be related to increased TRPC3 expression in the vascular endothelium.

questions.text: Post mortem lividity as shown in the photograph below is due to poisoning by _____
questions.solution:
The above photograph shows postmortem lividity with bright cherry red discolouration seen in Carbon monoxide poisoning.

  • Post mortem lividity or hypostasis or Livor mortis is the settling of blood under the influence of gravity which develops in the early post mortem interval.
  • Livor mortis starts in 20–30 minutes, but is usually not observable by the human eye until two hours after death. The size of the patches increases in the next three to six hours.
  • Lividity is said to become fixed between 8 and 12 hours after death, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.

Colour of post mortem lividity (hypostasis) in various conditions.

Condition Colour of hypostasis
Normal Bluish pink which later turns into bluish purple
Carbon monoxide poisoning Bright cherry red
Cyanide poisoning Pink
Phosphorus poisoning Dark brown
Nitrate poisoning Reddish brown
Chlorate poisoning Chocolate brown
Hydrogen sulphide poisoning Bluish Green
Aniline poisoning Deep blue
Opiate poisoning Black

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
The above image is diagnostic of Dental fluorosis.

Dental fluorosis (also termed mottled enamel) is an extremely common disorder, characterized by hypomineralization of tooth enamel caused by ingestion of excessive fluoride during enamel formation.

Mechanism:

  • In the extra-cellular environment of maturing enamel, an excess of fluoride ions alters the rate at which enamel matrix proteins (amelogenin) are enzymatically broken down and the rate at which the subsequent breakdown products are removed.
  • Fluoride may also indirectly alter the action of protease via a decrease in the availability of free calcium ions in the mineralization environment.
  • This results in the formation of enamel with less mineralization.
  • This hypomineralized enamel has altered optical properties and appears opaque and lustreless relative to normal enamel.

Classification:

The two main classification systems which are used in the grading of severity of dental fluorosis are Dean’s system and TF system.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The above image shows Black hairy tongue (BHT, also termed lingua villosa nigra).

  • BHT refers to a condition of the tongue where the filiform papillae elongate with black or brown discoloration, giving a black and hairy appearance. The appearance may be alarming, but it is a harmless condition.
  • Predisposing factors include smoking, xerostomia (dry mouth), soft diet, poor oral hygiene and certain medications (eg. Tetracyclines).

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Hairy tongue largely occurs in the central part of the dorsal tongue, just anterior (in front) of the circumvallate papillae, although sometimes the entire dorsal surface may be involved.
  • Patients may experience a gagging sensation or a bad taste.
  • There may also be associated oral malodour (intra-oral halitosis).

Treatment:

  • Management is by improving oral hygiene, especially scraping or brushing the tongue.
  • Keratolytic agents (chemicals to remove keratin) such as podophyllin are successful.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: There is perifollicular hyperkeratosis and keratotic papules
It is associated with liver cirrhosis and alcohol abuse
It can be seen in patients after bariatric surgery
It is predominantly associated with a deficiency of vitamin D

questions.solution:
The above image shows phrynoderma or toad skin. All the statements except statement 4 are true. Phrynoderma is predominantly associated with a deficiency of Vitamin A.  

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Phrynoderma is not specific to vitamin A deficiency, it is also seen in other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition.

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. 

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A. 
For children above 8 years and adults - 100,000 units daily for 3 days, followed by 50,000 units daily for 2 weeks and then 10,000 units daily for 2 months till liver stores are replenished.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the X-ray image shown below.
questions.solution:
The above X-ray radiograph shows the characteristic ‘coffee bean appearance’ seen in sigmoid volvulus.

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. Onset may be acute or chronic.

Investigations:

  • X-ray abdomen will show a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include:
    • Coffee bean sign
    • Frimann Dahl's sign - three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction
    • Absent rectal gas
  • CT may reveal a large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction
    • Whirl sign: twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels
    • Bird's beak sign: if rectal contrast has been administered

Treatment and prognosis:

Rectal tube insertion is successful in treating 90% of cases. The most serious complication is bowel ischemia.

Other options:

Midgut volvulus shows corkscrew appearance on barium study. The spiral appearance of the distal duodenum and proximal jejunum is responsible for the corkscrew appearance.

Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. The X-ray of cecal volvulus is given below.

Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure. This leads to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. The image given below is an X-ray of paralytic ileus.

questions.text: The urinary bladder shown in the MCU image below is diagnostic of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder, in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall. It is typically seen in severe neurogenic bladder.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.

There are five types of neurogenic bladder based on the site of the lesion.

  1. Sensory neurogenic bladder: Posterior columns of the spinal cord or afferent tracts leading from the bladder
  2. Motor paralytic bladder: Damage to motor neurons of the bladder
  3. Uninhibited neurogenic bladder: Incomplete spinal cord lesions above s2 or cerebral cortex or cerebropontine axis lesions
  4. Reflex neurogenic bladder: Complete spinal cord lesions above s2 - may lead to pine cone bladder
  5. Autonomous neurogenic bladder: Conus or cauda equina lesions

 

Note:

Occasionally, Christmas tree bladder is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought with complaints of premature development of breast buds. The sagittal MRI of the brain revealed a hypothalamic hamartoma. All of the following are used in the treatment of this patient, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central precocious puberty. GnRH antagonists are not used in the treatment of this patient.

Precocious puberty is defined as the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years in girls.

There are two types of precocious puberty:

  • Central/GnRH-dependent precocious puberty
  • Peripheral/GnRH-independent precocious puberty

Hypothalamic hamartomas are a neuronal migration defect that is the common cause of organic central precocious puberty. These lesions are believed to cause precocious puberty through the endogenous pulsatile release of GnRH, either independently or in concert with the GnRH-secreting neurons of the hypothalamus. 

Treatment of central precocious puberty:

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implants) are the treatment of choice for tumor-induced central precocious puberty.
  • Inj. depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) 100–200 mg, IM every 2–4 weeks to induce regression of these premature changes and cessation of menstruation.
  • Cyproterone acetate exerts antiandrogenic and antigonadotropin effects and is effective in treatment.
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (gamma knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: Identify the condition as shown below in the X-ray radiograph of a neonate
questions.solution:
This rare anterior defect of the diaphragm is commonly referred to as Morgagni, retrosternal, or parasternal hernia. The above X-ray radiograph shows congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Note the presence of bowel loops in the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm.
  • The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia; other types include Morgagni hernia, diaphragm eventration and central tendon defects of the diaphragm.
  • Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation.
  • CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of death due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Bochdalek hernia:

  • The Bochdalek hernia, also known as a postero-lateral diaphragmatic hernia, is the most common manifestation of CDH, accounting for more than 95% of cases.
  • In this instance the diaphragm abnormality is characterized by a hole in the postero-lateral corner of the diaphragm which allows passage of the abdominal viscera into the chest cavity.

Morgagni hernia:

  • This rare anterior defect of the diaphragm is commonly referred to as Morgagni, retrosternal, or parasternal hernia.
  • It accounts for approximately 2% of all CDH cases, and is characterized by herniation through the foramina of Morgagni which are located immediately adjacent and posterior to the xiphoid process of the sternum.

Diaphragm eventration:

  • Diaphragmatic eventration refers to an abnormal contour of the diaphragmatic dome.
  • Elevation of the affected portion of the diaphragm is usually seen as a smooth hump, while the remainder of the hemidiaphragm contour is normal.
  • This rare type of CDH occurs because in the region of eventration the diaphragm is thinner, allowing the abdominal viscera to protrude upwards.

Treatment:

  • The first step in management is orogastric tube placement and securing the airway (intubation).
  • The baby will usually be immediately placed on a ventilator.
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) has been used as part of the treatment strategy in some cases.

questions.text: Identify the type of cataract shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The cataract shown in the image is a morgagnian cataract which is identified by the presence of descent of the brown nucleus and emulsification of the cortex.

Morgagnian cataract is a form of hypermature senile cataract formed by liquefaction of the cortex and sinking of the dense nucleus to the bottom of the capsular bag. The liquefied cortex is milky, and the nucleus is usually seen as a brown mass limited above by a semicircular line. Changes in the position of the head cause alteration of the position of the nucleus.

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: A 75 year old man, who was on a tapering dose of methylprednisolone presented with complaints of non productive cough and chest pain. A chest CT scan revealed heterogeneous consolidation in the left upper lobe with cavitation. A biopsy showed the presence of a fungus, as seen in the image below. Voriconazole was started empirically for the infection. Identify the fungus based on its microscopic appearance:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a fungal respiratory infection in a patient taking corticosteroids along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of invasive aspergillosis caused by Aspergillus niger.

The microscopic appearance of Aspergillus niger is characterized by:

  • The vesicle is globular shaped
  • Phialides are in two rows
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black

Invasive disease may develop as an acute pneumonic process following the inhalation and germination of these conidia. Patients at risk for invasive aspergillosis are

  • lymphocytic or myelogenous leukemia and lymphoma
  • stem cell transplant recipients
  • individuals taking corticosteroids
  • AIDS patients with CD4 cell counts less than 50 CD4 cells/μL

Patients may present with fever, cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Hyphae may invade the lumens and walls of blood vessels leading to thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Rapid administration of native or lipid formulation of amphotericin B or voriconazole is indicated in these cases.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus

  • Vesicle is conical or flask shaped.
  • Phialides are arranged in a single row.
  • Conidia arise from upper third of the vesicle, and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus Flavus 

  • Vesicle is globular shaped.
  • Phialides are arranged in one or two rows.
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option D: Penicillium spp has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores. Chains of conidia are produced by 2 rows of sterigmata/phialides and give it a brush or broom appearance.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Auer Rods which are characteristically seen in AML.

  • Auer rods are clumps of azurophilic granular material that appear as elongated needles, seen in the cytoplasm of leukemic blasts.
  • They can be seen in the leukemic blasts of acute myeloid leukemia with maturation and acute promyelocytic leukemia (known as acute myeloid leukemia M2 and M3, in the FAB classification, respectively) and in high-grade myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative syndromes.
  • Morphologically, the Auer "rods" come in all sizes and shapes. They have been described as needle-shaped with pointed ends (most common), comma-shaped, and diamond-shaped; others were long and rectangular.
  • They are also used to distinguish the pre-leukemia myelodysplastic syndromes: refractory anemia with excess blasts 2 (RAEB2) (which has Auer rods) from RAEB 1 (which does not).

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: The emblem shown in the image below represents

choices.text: National Programme for control of blindness

questions.solution:
The emblem shown in the above image represents National Leprosy Eradication programme (NLEP).

Characteristics of NLEP emblem:

  • The NLEP Emblem symbolizes beauty and purity in lotus
  • Leprosy can be cured and a leprosy patient can be a useful member of the society in the form of a partially affected thumb; a normal fore-finger and the shape of house;
  • The symbol of hope and optimism in a rising sun.
  • The Emblem captures the spirit of hope positive action in the eradication of Leprosy.

The National Leprosy Eradication Programme is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

questions.text: The image below shows central catheter place in a patient on MHD. The catheter in this patient is commonly placed at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The above image shows tunnelled catheter which is commonly placed at the internal jugular vein.

  • For persons on maintenance hemodialysis, tunnelled catheters (either two separate catheters or a single catheter with two lumens) are often used when AV fistulas and grafts have failed or are not feasible due to anatomic considerations.
  • These catheters are tunnelled under the skin; the tunnel reduces bacterial translocation from the skin, resulting in a lower infection rate than with non-tunnelled temporary catheters.
  • Most tunnelled catheters are placed in the internal jugular veins; the external jugular, femoral, and subclavian veins may also be used.
  • Nephrologists, prefer to avoid placement of catheters into the subclavian.
  • Veins as subclavian stenosis is a frequent complication and, if present, will likely prohibit permanent vascular access (i.e., a fistula or graft) in the ipsilateral extremity.

questions.text: The reflex shown in the image below disappears at the age of _____
questions.solution:
The image above shows rooting reflex which disappears by the age of 4 months.

Rooting reflex:

  • A reflex that is seen in normal newborn babies, who automatically turn the face toward the stimulus and make sucking (rooting) motions with the mouth when the cheek or lip is touched.
  • The rooting reflex helps to ensure successful breastfeeding.
  • The reflex appears at 32 wks, it becomes less prominent after 1 month of birth and usually disappears by 3-4 months of age.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the out-patient with complaints of diminished vision along with floaters and flashes. The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument to assess the retinal lesions. Which of the following statements is true regarding the ophthalmoscopy done using the instrument shown in the image below?

choices.text: Area of field in focus is 2 disc diameters.
The image produced is real and inverted.

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and the procedure is known as indirect ophthalmoscopy.

An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted, or reversed, real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.

The area of field in focus is about 8 disc diameters.

It is a binocular, self-illuminated device where the condensing lens is usually required, and stereopsis is present.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: A 73 years old patient with a history of chronic congestive cardiac failure and secondary pulmonary hypertension was admitted in the ICU for severe breathlessness and pedal edema. The patient dies on the 2nd day of admission and an autopsy was done. On examination of abdominal viscera the liver was found to be enlarged with the following appearance on the cross-section of the specimen. False about this condition is:

choices.text: The pathology here is cirrhosis of liver
Diagnosis is based on Clinical evaluation

questions.solution:
This is an image of a "nutmeg" liver seen with chronic passive congestion of the liver. Note the dark red congested regions that represent the accumulation of RBC's in centrilobular regions.

Congestive hepatopathy is diffuse venous congestion within the liver that results from right-sided heart failure (usually due to cardiomyopathy, tricuspid regurgitation, mitral insufficiency, cor pulmonale, or constrictive pericarditis).

Pathogenesis:

  • Moderate or severe right-sided heart failure causes raised central venous pressure, which is transmitted to the liver via the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins.
  • Chronic congestion leads to atrophy of hepatocytes, distention of sinusoids, and centri zonal fibrosis, which, if severe, progresses to cirrhosis (cardiac cirrhosis).
  • The basis for liver cell death is probably sinusoidal thrombosis that propagates to the central veins and branches of the portal vein, causing ischemia.

Clinical Picture:

  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • However, moderate congestion causes right upper quadrant discomfort (due to stretching of the liver capsule) and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Ascites may result from the transmitted central venous hypertension; infrequently, splenomegaly results.
  • With transmitted central venous hypertension, the hepatojugular reflex is present, unlike in hepatic congestion due to Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on Clinical evaluation
  • Congestive hepatopathy is suspected in patients who have right-sided heart failure, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Laboratory test results are modestly abnormal: unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin < 3 mg/dL), elevated (usually < 2- to 3-fold) aminotransferases, and prolonged PT/INR.
  • Ascitic fluid, if present, has a high albumin content (typically > 2.5 g/dL); in contrast, only 10% of patients with cirrhotic ascites have ascitic albumin levels that high.
  • Because the laboratory abnormalities are nonspecific, recognition of congestive hepatopathy is ultimately clinical.

questions.text: The mosquito larvae shown in the image below is
questions.solution:
• The mosquito larva shown in the above image is anopheles larva.
  • The Anopheles larva is parallel to the water surface with a rudimentary breathing tube.
  • Whereas, the culex and Aedes larvae rest at an angle to the water surface.
  • The culex larva has short, stout breathing tube with one pair of hair tufts, whereas the aedes larva has long, slender breathing tube with several pairs of hair tufts.

Differentiating features between various stages of Anopheles, Culex and Aedes mosquitoes.

  Anopheles Culex  Aedes
Larvae

Rest parallel to the water surface

Rudimentary breathing tube

rest at an angle to the water surface 

Short, stout breathing tube with one pair of hair tufts

rest at an angle to the water surface 

Long slender breathing tube with several pairs of hair tufts
Pupae                   Differ only slightly
Adult Probocis and body in same straight line Probocis and body at an angle to one another  Probocis and body at an angle to one another

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

This is AIIMS pattern question. Detailed and thorough knowledge on cardiac cycle, pressures and volumes is a must for any entrance exam as it a frequently tested topic.
